greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Integers from 0 to A000120(n)-1 followed by integers from 0 to A000120(n+1)-1 and so on, starting with n=1.
example: For n=1, also 1 in binary notation, so the count of its 1-bits is 1 (A000120(1)=1), we list numbers from 0 to 0, thus just 0.
For n=2, 10 in binary, thus A000120(2)=1, we list numbers from 0 to 0, thus just 0.
For n=3, 11 in binary, thus A000120(3)=2, we list numbers from 0 to 1, and so we have the first four terms of the sequence: 0; 0; 0, 1;
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Jun 19 2014
